radiographic_examinations.findings: Osteochondroma in the left distal ulna, radial articular angle was 40 degrees, carpal slip of 50 percent, and ulnar shortening of 14 mm.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: At 2 weeks post-surgery, length of the ulna was corrected. At 2 months post-surgery, bone union occurred. At 8 years post-surgery, radial articular angle was 18 degrees, carpal slip was 10 percent, ulnar shortening was 5 mm, and the reconstructed growth plate had a tendency toward early union.

radiographic_examinations.findings: Multiple hereditary osteochondroma, radial articular angle was 35 degrees, carpal slip of 55 percent, and ulnar shortening of 22 mm.
radiographic_examinations.changes_over_time: At 2 weeks post-surgery, ulnar shortening was corrected. At 2 months post-surgery, bone union was observed. At 1 year post-surgery, radial articular angle was 30 degrees, carpal slip was 50 percent.
